artifact_name: drill(?); bodkin(?); pin; stylus(?); pin beater(?)
Description: Bone point. Possibly from a pin or alternatively a pin beater, stylus, drill, piercer, bodkin or point. Pointed, rounded half (third) of tube. Pollished surface. Chipped upper edge.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Ivory or bone pin, piercer or bodkin. Bone pin parallels from the Archaic Artemisia at Ephesus (Hogarth 1908, 186-9, Pl. XXXIII-XXXIV), but bodkins are probably closer parallels for these fragmentary pieces (Hogarth 1908, 186-9, Pl. XXXIV.40-43). Possibly an offering from a Greek sanctuary as with the examples found at Ephesus. Alternatively, parallels from Pompeii include pin beaters (used in weaving) or styli (Cool 2016, 214-5, 258-261). Cool, H. E. M. 2016. The small finds and vessel glass from Insula VI.1 Pompeii: Excavations 1995-2006. Oxford: Archaeopress, Roman Archaeology 17. Hogarth, D. G. 1908. Excavations at Ephesus: the Archaic Artemisia. London
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (WB.15) (Phase 3)
